new_figures.name: compression_tradeoff.png
new_figures.desc: Compression ratio vs speed scatter plot

user_argument_summary: For payloads < ~500-1000 B, stronger compression (zlib/zstd) does not amortize CPU cost
Total system cost (compression energy + transmission energy + memory pressure) favors LZ4/LZO on endpoints
PHY/MAC overhead often dominates airtime, so 20–30% fewer bytes may not meaningfully reduce radio energy
zlib and zstd require larger RAM/flash (Huffman, FSE, large buffers) conflicting with PQC buffer needs (e.g., Kyber)
LZ4/LZO have extremely low CPU cost, predictable execution, and cross the energy break-even point on constrained devices
Batching to justify zstd introduces higher RAM use, latency, and reliability tradeoffs—better suited for gateways
Predictable execution reduces side-channel risk and verification complexity
discussion_notes.agent_rationale_in_thesis: zlib and zstd were used as widely-adopted benchmark compressors and reference points for comparison; choice remains subject to endpoint vs gateway trade-offs
suggested_next_steps: Collect up-to-date references (2020–2025) comparing LZ4/LZO vs zlib/zstd on microcontrollers
Run microbenchmarks (CPU cycles, energy, RAM/flash) for payload sizes 16 B—2048 B on representative MCUs
Add a dedicated section or appendix discussing endpoint vs gateway compressor selection and PQC interactions

recommended_actions: Export summary to thesis appendix if desired
Run representative microbenchmarks and add results/plots to the thesis
Collect and add recent literature citations comparing IoT compressors and energy trade-offs
final_status: Thesis compiled cleanly; all figures integrated; next recommended work: add citations and/or run microbenchmarks
